when that guy asked about what happened if the ball speed was 0, i thought what would happen if we change the relative point of view   the Ball on earth may have a velocity of 0, but the earth is moving around the sun, the sun around the Galaxy and the Galaxy is moving (presumably) Away from what i call "Absolute Relative Point" or the center of the Universe where the big bang happened (hence absolute)   the most straight forward prediction i have is the wavelength varies depending on the point of view   let me explain   since P=h/Wavelength  then wavelength = h/p and p=m*v  the Wavelength = h/(m*v) v begin velocity   This states that the Relationship between Wavelength and Velocity is inverse, increasing the Velocity would result in shorter wavelengths and decreasing it will result in Longer wavelengths (all that is in the video) (also i imagine that if the object Velocity is 0, then the wavelength approach infinity then is pretty much a straight line)   But Velocity Varies depending on the Relative point of view  the ball velocity may be 0 on earth  meaning its wavelength approach infinity   but if we see the ball from the sun it is moving along the earth around the sun, therefore its velocity is equal to the velocity of the earth moving around this point of view, therefore it's wavelength is shorter than if we see it on earth   then it will be even shorter if we look at the ball from the center of the galaxy, because the sun moves way faster around the Galaxy than the earth around the sun  and i can only imagine how fast the Galaxy is moving from the Absolute center of the Universe, and how short that ball wavelength would be, or even the earth wavelength because its mass is bigger than the ball's mass  well my conclusive predictions of this is again, the Wavelength Varies Depending on the Relative Position of the observer

At 35:00, awnser to that question is straightforward. If the ball doesn't move it still contains momentum, because of the non zero temperature. The constituents are moving and do in fact have momentum, based on thermal physics. So the ball still has a tiny amount of momentum in the order of 10^-24 but this is still insignificant compared to planck's constant. Only when you get really really close to 0 kelvin you will have a macroscopic ball with quantum mechanical properties.

That's a stupid question. The basketball is not standing still, the atoms inside it are still oscillating and the de Broglie wavelength is proportional to the mass and the temperature. So since non of those change neither does the wavelength.
as you know, a circle of radius infinity is nothing but a line. hence, when a ball stops, its wavelength does become infinity, which means it is not moving in comparison to the average wavelength.

How did you calculate the momentum to get 10^-24 ? Also, has it been shown that macroscopic objects at near 0K display quantum mechanical properties?

Andrew Valmonte In the case of a solid ball it's actually quite hard to calculate cause it's a solid so we can't apply E = (3/2) n k T as in an ideal gas and it would even depend on the properties of the solid.  What you would want to know is the heat capacity of the bal i.e. how much energy do I need to raise the temperature of the ball with 1 degree. That bit of information is needed here, I did some research on google but I wasn't able to find the heat capacity of the type of ball mentioned here. Now we can assume most internal energy is kinetic, at least if we're not too close to 0K. If you have the heat capacity c you can multiply that with T(say 293K, room temperature) and that would give you a rough estimate of the internal energy.  When we have that we can assume that's the kinetic energy of all the molecules moving around in that ball, when we have the kin energy we can calculate the momentum using E = p²/2m and with that we can of course calculate the wavelength. In this case im not able to give an exact awnser/good approximiation because of lack of info about the ball's heat capacity, but it's still a lot of orders of magnitude above planck's constant. And we should not forget the heat capacity itself depends on temperature, it's only approximiately lineair on temperatures in every day life, so depending on how accurate you want an awnser it can get very tricky.   And about that 0K story, no this hasn't been shown. The reason is no one has ever come close enough to 0K for these effects to get significant, im not going to calculate that now but you would have to get incredibly close to 0K for those effects, orders of magnitude closer than what today's technology can do. However you could get those effects with intermediate objects like large molecules that as a whole may not be really behaving quantummechanically at normal temperatures but can experimentally be cooled to sufficiently cold temperatures. So within the technological limits this has been proven experimentally. Hope this helps you further, and in any case you could even experimentally determine the heat capacity of a given ball if needed :p   EDIT: something went wrong when I applied this to a piece of iron of 1 kg. The value for the momentum of a (macroscopically) stationairy piece of iron get's too high, even higher than what it should be at low speeds. Probably my assumption on the composition of internal energy is wrong, if most of the energy isn't kinetic the above description doesn't work. Damn, by explicitely trying to work this out it turns out to be harder than I thought.

Dirk-Jan Toot Andrew Valmonte Experimental scientists have been able to get materials to temperatures extremely close to zero kelvin (0 K), although because of vacuum energy it is impossible to actually reach 0K, they've gotten things to less than 1 kelvin (within hundredths of degrees above absolute zero). It has been observed that yes macroscopic objects start to have quantum mechanical properties and verry, verry odd properties like super-conduction and properties of super-fluids. (i would recommend researching it a bit, it's really cool stuff )

Good question from the student: "How about the wavelength of the ball as it stops ?" To answer this, we need to recite Heisenberg's uncertainty principle. The speed would never be ideally zero since you know the position of the ball to a certain precision (for example 10^-6 m) . This lead to the uncertain in speed, and the wavelength of the ball is still very small. Do the maths to verify!
